I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  In July 2014, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) became a member of the Open 
Government Partnership (OGP) to help strengthen the governance principles of openness, 
transparency, accountability, and participation in Asia and the Pacific. This proposal responds to 
a direct invitation from the OGP Steering Committee1 and from three OGP member countries for 
ADB to support government and civil society actors to advance open government across the 
region. This capacity development technical assistance (TA) seeks to support OGP member 
countries to formulate and implement commitments made in the OGP national action plans 
(NAPs).2 The TA will also provide learning opportunities for aspiring member countries to meet 
OGP eligibility status in the areas of access to information, budget transparency, income and 
asset disclosure, and citizen engagement. The project design and monitoring framework is in 
Appendix 1.3  
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  The recently launched Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) highlight the need for 
public access to information as a building block for promoting peaceful and inclusive societies 
for development. The SDG Goal number 16 aims to “promote peaceful and inclusive societies 
for sustainable development, provide access to justice for all, and build effective, accountable, 
and inclusive institutions at all levels”. It further defines at least three targets that this project will 
significantly  contribute  to.  These  are  Targets  16.6  (develop  effective,  accountable  and 
transparent  institutions  at  all  levels),  16.7  (Ensure  responsive,  inclusive,  participatory  and 
representative decision-making at all levels), and 16.10 (Ensure public access to information 
and protect fundamental freedoms, in accordance with national legislation and international 
agreements). These targets underscore the importance of information platforms that would 
make governments more effective, transparent, and accountable, as well as ensure that citizens 
participate in governance processes.  
 
3.  The Open Government Partnership was formally launched in September 2011, when its 
eight founding governments (Brazil, Indonesia, Mexico, Norway, the Philippines, South Africa, 
the United Kingdom, and the United States) endorsed the Open Government Declaration, and 
announced their country action plans. The OGP is a “multilateral initiative that aims to secure 
concrete commitments from governments to promote transparency, empower citizens, fight 
corruption, and harness new technologies to strengthen governance.”4 It is a voluntary initiative 
that aims at building trust and fostering collaboration between governments and their citizens to 
improve development outcomes. In order to join OGP, an aspiring member country must first 
satisfy  the  “eligibility  criteria.”  This  means  that  a  minimum  level  of  commitment  to  open 
government principles, in the following four areas has to be met: (i) budget transparency; (ii) 
access to information; (iii) income and asset disclosure; and (iv) citizen engagement. Once 
eligibility has been confirmed, the interested government needs to identify a lead ministry and/or 
agency that will start formulating the NAP in close consultation with civil society and citizen

groups. The NAPs contain the members’ respective reform commitments over a 2-year period.5  
The ultimate goal is to improve the quality of governance, as well as the quality of projects and 
services that citizens receive. The OGP aspires to support both government and civil society 
reformers by elevating open government to the highest levels of political discourse, providing 
cover for difficult reforms, and creating a supportive community of like-minded reformers from 
countries around the world.  
 
4.  In  2014,  ADB  became  a  multilateral  partner  of  the  OGP  to  support  its  developing 
member  countries  (DMCs),  which  have  become  OGP  members,  implement  their  open 
government  action  plans.  The  ADB  also  supports  aspiring  member  countries  to  meet  the 
eligibility criteria for joining the OGP.6 ADB’s partnership with the OGP is based on the long-
term  commitment  to  supporting  multi-stakeholder  governance  initiatives.  ADB’s  recent 
Governance  Thematic  Group  (GovTG)  position  paper  on  better  performing  institutions 
recognizes the importance of institutional performance and results. At the outcome level, the 
aim  is  to  facilitate  performing,  responsive  and  resilient  institutions  that  deliver  better 
development results to citizens. Immediate outputs include better governance and accountability 
mechanisms, systems and business processes, new and enhanced skills and management 
practices as well as greater attention to and support of multi-stakeholder coalitions that can 
drive  reform  and  change.7 ADB’s  partnership  with  the  OGP  is  highly  consistent  with  the 
approach described in the position paper, because of the OGP’s focus on facilitating better 
institutions that deliver better development results, as well as its emphasis on multi-stakeholder 
participation and collaboration between governments and citizens.   
 
5.  Eight  OGP  member  countries  among  ADB’s  DMCs  (Armenia,  Georgia,  Indonesia, 
Mongolia, the Philippines, Papua New Guinea, and Sri Lanka) have made a commitment to 
work toward improving the participation of citizens and civil society in the formulation and 
implementation of their NAPs, and have requested for ADB support in this process. The DMCs 
are at different stages of implementation with Armenia, Georgia, Indonesia, Mongolia and the 
Philippines  showing  impressive  initial  results  in  selected  OGP  areas,  notably  Indonesia’s 
“Responsive Open Data Model. However, often the reforms are introduced on a pilot basis 
notwithstanding the important need to roll out reforms across the country and to institutionalize 
successful pilots. The next step will require extensive training of key government agencies, 
citizens and civil society organizations (CSOs), and improve business processes. Successful 
reform  programs  vary from  country  to  country.  Hence,  there  is  a great  potential for  OGP 
countries to share knowledge and experience on successful reforms in the region. It is also 
recognized that better understanding and relationship of trust need to be established among key 
stakeholder  groups,  especially  in  countries  which  historically,  had  not  been  able  to 
institutionalize meaningful citizen participation in decision-making.   
 
6.  Past ADB support to strengthen civil society participation in OGP includes the regional 
TA on Governance and Capacity Development Initiative (Phase 2). It has supported workshops 
for both government and civil society OGP focal persons from DMCs to take stock of their joint

OGP  participation.  ADB  also  facilitated  three  regional  events,8 to  share  knowledge  and 
innovative ways by which governments engage with their citizens and CSOs, targeting both 
OGP member countries, as well as those who aspire to join. As a result of such knowledge 
sharing and networking events, several OGP countries have been encouraged to replicate 
successful approaches of specific governance reforms areas that that have worked in other 
OGP member countries. As an example, providing greater data transparency has generated 
strong interest from several countries that would like to make better use of the digital revolution.  
Countries such as the Philippines have been reviewing options for introducing Freedom of 
Information legislation that have successfully been institutionalized in other countries, such as 
India. In addition, hosting successful events for DMC officials, CSOs and other development 
partners has increasingly recognized ADB as a knowledge organization which can contribute 
immensely to improving governance at the country level. ADB’s regional departments have 
recognized that there was government demand for transparent and accountable institutions in 
some countries and increasingly saw potential to include such OGP initiatives in their lending 
portfolios.    
  
III.  THE CAPACITY DEVELOPMENT TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
7.  The  impact  will  be  increased  collaboration  between  governments  and  civil  society 
organizations in Asia and the Pacific to enhance accountability and transparency in public 
service delivery. The outcome will be a strengthened collaboration between the government and 
civil society to support citizen participation in service delivery. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
8.  The TA will contribute to the formulation and implementation of specific actions included 
in the OGP NAPs and will support broader OGP knowledge generation and sharing through 
three outputs.9 The participating countries (Armenia, Indonesia, and Papua New Guinea) were 
selected based on their demand for ADB assistance to help them formulate and implement their 
NAPs. Another important criterion was the strong link of the proposed TA with ongoing or 
planned lending operations and the related demand from regional departments for inclusion in 
the TA. This resulted in the inclusion of Armenia and Indonesia in the TA. Papua New Guinea 
recently joined the OGP and will be finalizing and rolling out their NAP implementation.  
 
9.  Output 1: Knowledge products on open government partnership developed and 
disseminated.  Output  1  will  prepare  a  training  needs  assessment  report  which  identifies 
knowledge and skills required of government agencies and CSOs in the three OGP countries, to 
be able to carry out reforms and promote transparency, better access to information, and 
improved citizen engagement, among others. Consultation meetings with key government and 
civil  society  representatives  will  be  organized  to  recommend  ways  to  strengthen  citizen 
engagement in governance, expand information sharing, and improve service delivery. Based 
on  recommendations,  a  program  for  building  the  capacity  of  government  and  civil  society 
representatives for more transparent and accountable governance will be developed. 
 
10.  Output 2: Capacity of stakeholders in selected DMCs to promote and implement 
the NAP strengthened. Output 2 will conduct training programs and cross-learning events from 
                                                
8  Knowledge events were held on September 2015, November 2015, and July 2016. 
9  This TA will only provide support to OGP member countries, which are also ADB’s developing member countries.

4    
 
Asia-Pacific  OGP  members  and  AMCs  on  subjects  related  to  the  following:  (i) information 
sharing; (ii) open data, including data collection and data analysis; (iii) use of information and 
communication  technology  (ICT)  for  improved  governance;  (iv)  implementing  the  right  to 
information; and (v) citizens’ engagement in the Asia-Pacific OGP. The training and learning will 
be identified from output 1 in the areas listed from (i) to (v).  
 
11.  Output 3: Community-based initiative on monitoring government service delivery 
pilot tested. Output 3 will provide of technical and demonstration support for carrying out the 
implementation of action plans through subproject training to communities by the OGP and civil 
society on NAPs. The projects were selected based on demand from the OGP government focal 
points. The output comprises innovative initiatives to use technology for data sharing, data 
analysis,  information  sharing  monitoring,  as  well  as  to  strengthen  citizen  engagement  to 
improve service delivery in two countries requested by their governments. Output 3 has two 
subprojects:   
 
(i)  Subproject 3.1. Improved service delivery processes and open data procedures are 
disseminated  and  rolled  out  in  two  additional  subnational  governments.  At  the 
request  of  the  OGP  focal  point  in  Indonesia,  the  TA  will  support  innovative 
approaches to improve service delivery processes and open data procedures at the 
subnational level in Indonesia. The subproject will build on earlier work conducted in 
Banda Aceh under the Kinerja project financed by the United States Agency for 
International Development. Kinerja introduced demand- and supply-side approaches 
to use open data for public service delivery improvements. The Kinerja activities in 
Banda Aceh ended in September 2015. ADB is deepening the Kinerja activities in 
Banda  Aceh  under  a  component  of  the  regional  capacity  development  TA  on 
Delivering  Knowledge  Solutions  in  Asia  and  the  Pacific10   to  strengthen  citizen 
engagement and data quality. Implementation has started in October 2016 and will 
end in April 2017. Subproject 3.1 will utilize the Banda Aceh good practice developed 
under the Kinerja project and the regional capacity development TA on Knowledge 
Solutions in Asia and the Pacific to disseminate information at the national level, in 
close  cooperation  with  the  OGP  focal  point.  An  additional  two  subnational 
governments will be selected and supported for strengthening their demand- and 
supply-side approaches to use open data for public service delivery improvements in 
selected sectors. The results will be scaled up through a policy-based loan on Public 
Financial Management for Service Delivery in the 2018 indicative lending pipeline for 
Indonesia.11  
 
(ii) Subproject 3.2. The subproject aims to support Armenia to reduce potential integrity 
and safeguards risks under the Seismic Safety Improvement Program (SSIP), an 
ADB project approved by ADB’s Board of Directors on 22 September 2015.12 The 
subproject is to test a community-based integrity initiative pilot project, which will help 
the  government  to  monitor  the  rehabilitation  and  reconstruction  of  schools  with 
adequate seismic safety in Armenia under the SSIP. By using training community 
monitors to observe and monitor school reconstruction under the SSIP, the pilot 
project will contribute to schools with better structural integrity and seismic safety by 
(i) reducing the risks of resource leakage in the construction process, (ii) ensuring

C.  Cost and Financing 
 
12.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,000,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by the 
Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction and administered by ADB.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
13.  ADB will be the executing agency of the TA project, which will be implemented from 
February 2017 to February 2019. The Thematic Advisory Service Cluster of the Sustainable 
Development and Climate Change Department will be responsible for administering the TA 
activities. Subproject 3.1 will be administered by the GovTG Secretariat of ADB and subproject 
3.2 will be administered by the NGO and Civil Society Center. The TA will coordinate with the 
OGP secretariat and the OECD’s Open Government Network to call on these two institution’s 
experts for the purpose of information sharing and cross learning at training events. The two 
subprojects under output 3 will be jointly implemented with relevant regional departments and 
the country OGP focal points.  
 
14.   The TA will finance consulting services, reports, and other knowledge products, as well 
as workshops and other knowledge and learning events. The TA will provide international 
consultants (18 person-months) and national consultants (66 person-months). The expertise 
includes access to information, budget transparency, income and asset disclosure, and citizen 
engagement. The outline terms of reference are in Appendix 3. The terms of reference for 
consultants  will  be  further  developed  when  specific  activities  are  undertaken.  Given  the 
intermittence of the assignments and the variety of skills required, consultants will be recruited 
individually in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2013, as amended 
from time to time) and with output-based contracts and lump sum out of pocket expenses 
wherever possible.  
 
15.  Output 3.2 will utilize letters of agreement and recruitment of consultants to work with 
CSOs to carry out the training activities, using the milestone achievements under the identified 
work plan as references for output-based performance contracts and lump-sum out-of-pocket 
expenses, wherever possible. Integrity Action, the partner organization will provide national and 
international consultants to conduct activities listed in the design and monitoring framework.    
   
16.  All  disbursements  under  the TA  will  be  made  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). In the event that 
ADB staff act as resource persons in the implementation of the TA, travel and related costs will 
be charged to the TA. However, their salaries and benefits will be charged to ADB’s internal 
administrative expenses budget.   
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
Asian Development Bank administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of 
$1,000,000 to be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction for 
Strengthening Government and Civil Society Cooperation in Open Government Partnership to 
Improve Public Services, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  About 18 person-months (intermittent) of international and 66 person-months of national 
consulting services will be required to ensure the effective implementation of this technical 
assistance (TA) project. All consultants will be recruited in accordance with the Guidelines on 
the Use of Consultants (2013, as amended from time to time) of the Asian Development Bank. 
Detailed terms of reference will be finalized as the specific scope of work is determined based 
on consultations with participating developing member countries. 
 
A.  International and National Institutional Development and Governance Consultants  
 
2.  The TA will secure 18 person-months of international and 66 person-months of national 
consulting services with expertise in governance, government budgetary process, institutional 
development,  citizens’  engagement,  accountability  systems,  and  open  data  and  access  to 
information and anticorruption. The consultants will undertake the following activities, among 
others: 
 
(i)  conduct consultation and research in cooperation with the Open Government 
Partnership  (OGP)  focal  departments  and/or  ministries  on  the  OGP  national 
action plan (NAP) process, implementation, and eligibility criteria; and identify 
areas of capacity development needs; 
(ii)  produce a recommendation report for follow-up training; 
(iii)  based on the findings of the recommendation report, design and lead country-
specific  capacity  development  training  on  citizens’  engagement  in  the  OGP 
process, sharing of information, and how governments can be more open to the 
public and civil society; 
(iv)  conduct a follow-up assessment to evaluate the impact of the TA outputs; 
(v)  communicate and coordinate with partner international organizations, including 
the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development and the OGP 
Support Unit with respect to the implementation of the TA project; 
(vi)  regularly report the progress of the TA project; 
(vii)  conduct open data research and replication projects to local governments; 
(viii)  produce reports and knowledge products to share inside the country and with 
regional OGP focal person and OGP focal ministries and/or department; and 
(ix)  conduct national and international workshops to disseminate findings. 
 
3.  The terms of reference for the consultant will be further developed when specific TA 
activities are undertaken. 
 
B.  Project Support Coordinator 
4.  The TA will provide about 18 person-months (intermittent) individual national consulting 
services to support the management and coordination of the TA implementation. Activities will 
include the following: 
  
(i)  prepare and organize documents for the TA implementation; 
(ii)  serve as analyst on project implementation;  
(iii)  draft memo, letters, and contract variations on change of scope, invitation, and 
other documents as needed to implement activities listed in the TA; and 
(iv)  work  closely  with  the  Asian  Development  Bank’s  Operations  Services  and 
Financial  Management  Department,  Controller’s  Department,  Office  of  the
